name: electricity production, hard coal, supercritical | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The share of units with flue gas desulphurisatoin (FGD) will change over the time period (this is entered as a parameter). Currently only one-third of the units have FGD, but ultimately all units will have FGD (estimated to be in 10 years time). The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2016 (only one unit in commerical operation). Annual production volume will increase year on year as new units are being brought on line.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is representative of new build supercritical coal fired power plants in South Africa. Features unique to the South African context are covered, such as dry cooling and coal characteristics (high ash, low calorific value coals).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is representative of new and future build coal-fired power stations in South Africa. Each station is planned to have six 800 MW units. The supercritical pulverised fuel boilers (net efficiency of 37%) are dry cooled with pulse jet fabric filters for particulate control. The stations either have wet limestone flue gas desuphurisation (FGD) on commissioning or this is planned for retrofit. The stations do not have selective catalytic reduction (SCR) for NOx abatement. The stations are planned for base load generation, with a generation load factor of 85%.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Emissions to air other than CO2, N2O, NOx, SOx, particulates and Hg are taken from the existing ecoivent dataset, where the following comments apply: 

Data from 1993 were updated for the years 2000 (v1.0), and 2004-2005 (v2.0). Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly. 

Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US.

The original data were valid for the burning of 1MJ of hard coal. In this dataset, the values are scaled to the net output of 1kWh of electricity, based on the electrical efficiency.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Technical performance data (modelled values) taking into account the coal characteristics and technology to be employed at power stations currently under construction, including efficiency, coal, water, limestone (for flue gas desulphurisation), ash waste and major emissions (carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide and particulates). Mercury emissions are taken from the literature (Garnham and Langeman, 2016). Power station infrastructure and all other emissions to air are taken from the existing electricity production from hard coal dataset in ecoinvent (see extrapolation comment). Sources: Power Generation Technology Data for Integrated Resource Plan of South Africa. EPRI, Palo Alto, CA: 2015; Garnham, B and Langeman, K (2016) Mercury emissions from South Africa’s coal-fired power stations, Clean Air Journal, Vol. 26, No2, 2016. Available at: http://www.cleanairjournal.org.za/download/caj_vol26_no2_2016_p14.pdf

exchanges.description: This is power sent out from power station, i.e. net power generated after allowing for own use

exchanges.description: From new build performance characteristics (the value is the same with and without FGD). The figure reported is total particulates only, so the size distribution is taken from the existing ecoinvent dataset for electricity production from hard coal (based on German data), i.e. 25% of the particulate emissions are < 2.5um, 72% are > 10 um and 3% are between 2.5 um and 10 um. Source: Power Generation Technology Data for Integrated Resource Plan of South Africa. EPRI, Palo Alto, CA: 2015

flow.name: Particulate Matter, < 2.5 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Value not specific to South Africa or supercritical power plants. Generic value from previous ecoinvent dataset, with original comment as follows: Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 14 countries 
(AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US) (Röder et al. 2007) 
Country emissions values calculated from trace element balance, input uncertain

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

flow.name: Manganese II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: The one new build power station is being built with a limestone forced oxidation system wet scrubber that will achieve 95% removal of inlet SO2. The SO2 retained is thus calculated as 95% of the SO2 for those units with flue gas desulphurisation (FGD). SO2 emissions from performance characteristics of new build power plants taking into account coal characteristics, boiler technology and coal burn rate. exchanges.description: Mercury emissions approximated by Eskom's coal-fired power stations employing fabric filter plants (FFP) for particulate emissions abatement, from a study by Garnham and Langeman (2016). Calculated value based on the amount of coal burnt per annum per power station, the mercury content (ppm) of the coal used at each power and  mercury emission reduction factors for fabric filters sourced from the US EPA (2013) and UNEP (2015). The lower end of the range determined for FFPs by Garnham and Langeman is assumed to approximate fabric filters plus wet FGD (the EPA Emissions Reduction Factors is very similar for FFP and FFP+wet FGD) whilst the average value is applied for FFP without FGD. Overall approach is that of ‘Toolkit for Identification and Quantification of Mercury Releases’ (UNEP 2015). Source: Garnham, B and Langeman, K (2016) Mercury emissions from South Africa’s coal-fired power stations, Clean Air Journal, Vol. 26, No2, 2016. Available at: http://www.cleanairjournal.org.za/download/caj_vol26_no2_2016_p14.pdf

flow.name: Arsenic ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: From new build performance characteristics (the value is the same with and without FGD). The figure reported is total particulates only, so the size distribution is taken from the existing ecoinvent dataset for electricity production from hard coal (based on German data), i.e. 25% of the particulate emissions are < 2.5um, 72% are > 10 um and 3% are between 2.5 um and 10 um. Source: Power Generation Technology Data for Integrated Resource Plan of South Africa. EPRI, Palo Alto, CA: 2015

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 2.5 um and < 10um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Water losses to air are assumed to equal the boiler water makeup, with boiler makeup from new build performance characteristics (without FGD). Water for boiler makeup and FGD are the only water requirements as new build power stations are dry cooled. All water use at the power station is consumptive, i.e. there are no return flows to rivers. In the power station water plants, water use is optimised through cascading water quality cycles. Any remaining water of too poor quality to be used is stored in dams on site. All water loss is therefore assumed to be evaporative, i.e. steam leaks and evaporation from storage ponds. Potential seepage losses from storage ponds are not accounted for due to a lack of data, as are occasional spills from storage dams in high rainfall events. Source :Power Generation Technology Data for Integrated Resource Plan of South Africa. EPRI, Palo Alto, CA: 2015

flow.name: Toluene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Value not specific to new build, but the average for Eskom's existing fleet of power stations. The figure reported by Eskom is a calculated figure based on power station design parameters, coal characteristics and coal tonnages burnt, and includes coal-fired and gas turbine power stations (burning diesel), as well as oil consumed during power station start-ups. The Eskom figure has been adjusted using the IPCC default N2O emission factor for Gas/Diesel oil combustion in energy industries and the quantity of diesel burnt by Eskom to deduct the N2O emissions from the OCGT power stations. Source: Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf
